revision.text:
'''Wendell E. Reed''' was an aircraft engineer noted primarily for inventing the engine microjet controller (EMC), for which he was awarded the [[Wright Brothers Medal]] in 1955.<ref name=reed_1>{{cite journal|title=Inventor Award|year=1956|page=206|volume=90|journal=The Aeroplane|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZgYnAAAAMAAJ&q=%22wright+brothers+medal%22+-langley&dq=%22wright+brothers+medal%22+-langley&hl=en&ei=-GQGTeiXOaW2nAeotJXlDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CEgQ6AEwCTg8}}</ref><ref name=reed_2>{{cite journal|title=Announcement|year=1956|page=175|volume=19|journal=American Aviation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wUSmHaXIzX4C&q=%22wright+brothers+medal%22+-langley&dq=%22wright+brothers+medal%22+-langley&hl=en&ei=-GQGTeiXOaW2nAeotJXlDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAjg8}}</ref><ref name=flight_1955>[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1955/1955%20-%201727.html Pneumatic Control for Turbojets and Ramjets: A New System by Solar] (1955) ''Flight'' '''68'''(2445), 847.</ref> Reed's experiences in the [[United States Army Air Forces|USAAF]] piloting the [[North American B-25 Mitchell|B-25]] kindled a lifelong interest in flight and he later completed his degree at [[University of Wisconsinâ€“Madison|University of Wisconsin]] in Mechanical Engineering.<ref name=ut_2005>Williams, J. (2005) [http://www.utsandiego.com/uniontrib/20050402/news_1m2reed.html Wendell E. Reed; prestigious award winner at Solar] ''[[U-T San Diego|San Diego Union-Tribune]]'', April 2, 2005.</ref> He subsequently joined [[Solar Turbines|Solar Aircraft Co]], where he developed the EMC.
